subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: Hello All, I think we go through this conversation about every 3-6 months. One thing is not everything to all.  QS is a phonic character set based on British
messageBody:
Hello All,

I think we go through this conversation about every 3-6 months. One thing is not everything to all.  QS is a phonic character set based on British English. The use of it assumes that the person can relate to the text that describes the character sound. Beyond that the only other way to define the character's sound would be an oral pronunciation of each character.

A audio tape or CD could definitely set a standard sound byte for each character. Then we could all use it as proposed, as a phonic representation of our oral conversation. Any attempt to change the sound byte for each character to fit different dialects would be counter to QS's original purpose.

One character needs to only represent one sound. Which character we use to express our words all depends on our accuracy in hearing and analyzing our own words in relationship to the sound bytes associated with the QS characters.


I propose we build an audio library as a reference to the sound of each QS character. In staying with the heart of Reed's original intent, I think this audio library should be done in British English. Then everyone can use a repeatable set of sounds/characters to represent their communications.


Chuck Peck
cak pek  < Jerome font

-----Original Message-----
From: Steve Bett [mailto:sbett@...]
Sent: Wednesday, January 05, 2005 3:31 AM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: American pronunciation



A phoneme represents a range of sounds or a category of sounds recognized by a speech community.  The range of sounds recognized as a particular word varies from word to word. 

One locates phonemes by finding at least one minimal pair.  A pair of words which will change meaning if one feature is allowed to
vary: e.g. The existance of pit/pet means that the short i and short e are both English phonemes.

If one dictionary pronunciation guide will not work for two dialects of English, then there may also be problems with a phonemic notation. Pitman argued that his i/t/a notation was not a pronunciation guide since each locale determined what constituted an ey sound.

An Australian probably has no difficulty distinguishing DAY and DIE but an American might confuse the two "strine pronunciations.



--- "Joe" <allegrox_2000@y...> wrote:

>
> Read did set standards for certain prefixes and suffixes,
fully
expecting standards to develop for others.  (His can be found in the Quikscript Manual, by the way.) 

SB: I presume the manual is in the file section.

The solution that's been proposed for Shavian is to define the sounds of letters with sample words and to allow the writer to use the letter as (s)he pronounces it in that particular word. 

Since sound changes are fairly uniform throughout any dialect, this should still represent the same phoneme.  For example, we could say that /E/ represents the vowel found in "day", and it will always be used for that phoneme, no matter how you actually pronounce it. 

SB: Would E indicate /aI/ in Oz-speak?

If your dialect says [F], you still write /E/, and you do it consistently.  Australians will just learn a different sound-sign assignment and pronounce it their way unless they're speaking in a different accent.


I'm reminded of an article on the value of morphemic spelling, which you can find here:
http://www.spellingsociety.org/journals/j2/gregersen.html

SB: If you spell kids and boys with an s, then you are engaged in morphemic spelling which says that the plural will be spelled <s> no matter how it is pronounced.  boyz = boys. 

--Steve

I think we go through this conversation about every 3-6 months. One thing is
not everything to all.  QS is a phonic character set based on British
